departments.name: Biochemistry, Structural, and Molecular Cell Biology

faculty.name: David Chan
faculty.requirements: Bi8, Bi9
faculty.opportunities: molecular biology, cell biology

faculty.name: Andre Hoelz
faculty.requirements: none
faculty.students: Krystal Brodsky, formerly Ellen Yu, Sarah Cai
faculty.opportunities: Biochemistry/Structural Biology

faculty.name: Carlos Lois
faculty.opportunities: computational analysis of behavior, structure of brain circuits

faculty.name: Niles Pierce
faculty.requirements: algorithms and programming  -or- wet lab experience -or- both
faculty.students: Yuhan Xie (Univ Cambridge), Lachlan Deimel (Australian Nat Univ), Bergthor Traustason (Univ Iceland), Andrew Hou (BE)
faculty.opportunities: Imaging subgroup: dynamic nucleic acid nanotechnology for multiplexed quantitative imaging of the programmable molecules of life (DNA, RNA, proteins); Regulation subgroup: programmable conditional regulation via dynamic RNA nanotechnology with small conditional RNAs; Algorithms subgroup: mathematically rigorous, physically sound, computationally efficient algorithms for the analysis and design of nucleic acid structures, devices, and systems.

faculty.name: Paul Sternberg
faculty.requirements: Interest
faculty.opportunities: Genetics of behavior and development; neural circuits; natural language processing; genomics

faculty.name: Kai Zinn
faculty.requirements: At least one biology lab course
faculty.opportunities: We do Drosophila neurogenetics and molecular biology.

faculty.name: Elliot Meyerowitz
faculty.requirements: Some lab experience, in any area
faculty.opportunities: To work with postdoctoral fellow Eldad Afik on characterizing movement of organelles, and regeneration, in the marine alga Caulerpa.

faculty.name: David Prober
faculty.requirements: Biology or related field major
faculty.opportunities: Research opportunities include working with graduate students and postdocs to study genes and neurons that regulate sleep. Projects involve molecular and behavioral neuroscience, genetics, and molecular biology.

faculty.name: Elliot Meyerowitz
faculty.requirements: 3-D printing design and printing
faculty.opportunities: As a part of our plant research we need to develop an automated hydroponic system.  The project would be development of the CAD plans for 3D printing a hydroponic live-imaging system for observation of the shoot apical meristem and testing its effectiveness.

faculty.name: Joseph Parker
faculty.opportunities: Insect transgenesis

faculty.name: Carol Readhead
faculty.requirements: Students should have a major interest in Developmental biology and working with animals
faculty.opportunities: Histology,  immunohistochemistry and imaging of embryos.  Analysis of images

faculty.name: Elizabeth Hong
faculty.requirements: Programming and fabrication skills useful but not necessary. Must be intellectually curious. Must commit to a minimum of 9 hrs/week for two or more terms (which can include summer research).
faculty.opportunities: Computational modeling, behavioral experiments, analytical chemistry, molecular cloning and genome engineering, extracellular electrophysiology

faculty.name: Shinsuke Shimojo
faculty.requirements: Some neuroscience, bioengineering, psychology related courses, ability of coding in Matlab, Python or C++.
faculty.students: Lily Kitagawa, Steve Guo, Ishani Ganguly, Sara Adams, Anthony Pineci
faculty.opportunities: Assisting human psychophysics (sensation, decision, action) experiments, in coding, running, and analyzing. Human magnetic sensation, Individual and Team flow, visual preference decision, perception and action in the extreme periphery of visual field, etc.

faculty.name: Markus Meister and Zeynep Turan
faculty.requirements: Previous experience working with rodents is a plus, but not required.
faculty.students: Sarah Sam (Amgen Scholar), Brittany Percin (Caltech UG pre-med)
faculty.opportunities: Can the laboratory mice become efficient hunters when challenged with the task of foraging for food? Can a naive animal learn from a professional hunter? If you are interested in naturalistic behaviors, gaining experience in experimental design and data analysis, join us.

faculty.name: Ralph Adolphs
faculty.requirements: Must have coding experience, preferably in Python
faculty.students: Rae Moar, Louis Santos, Roshan Bal, Isabella Camplisson
faculty.opportunities: Working on human data, likely either brain imaging data and/or eyetracking data; applying machine learning algorithms to find patterns in the data.  Will work with graduate students and/or post-docs in the lab.

faculty.name: Richard Murray
faculty.requirements: Either Bi 1X (for students interested in synthetic biology) or CS 1/2 (for students interested  in robotics and controls).  Other useful classes: ChE 130, CS 142/413, CDS 110.
faculty.students: Liana Merk, Sophie Walton, Shuyue Yu, Victoria Chen, JD Walker
faculty.opportunities: My group's research is in the application of feedback and control to networked systems, with applications in biology and autonomy. Current projects include work on biomolecular feedback systems, novel architectures for control systems, and networked control systems.

faculty.name: Bil Clemons
faculty.requirements: Previous protein and cloning experience preferred but not required. Enthusiasm and commitment is the biggest driver. Freshman can join the lab if they have previous experience.
faculty.opportunities: Students typically start in my group assisting a mentor towards a specific project. After demonstrating independence, students can take on their own independent project. We are primarily a structural biology group and start with protein expression and purification that allows for various structural studies.

faculty.name: Lea Goentoro
faculty.requirements: Curiosity, creativity, courage to try new things.  Love finding things out, and diligent (read background literature).  Prefer students who are looking for a long-term, in-depth research project.
faculty.opportunities: Research in inducing regeneration in animal.  An ideal candidate pursues their own independent project in the problem of inducing regeneration in animal.  Project formulated together with the professor, new ideas are welcome and encouraged. There are multiple model organisms in the lab.

faculty.name: Carol Readhead
faculty.requirements: Students should have a major interest in Developmental biology and working with animals
faculty.opportunities: Histology,  immunohistochemistry and imaging of embryos.  Analysis of images

faculty.name: Elizabeth Hong
faculty.requirements: Programming and fabrication skills useful but not necessary. Must be intellectually curious. Must commit to a minimum of 9 hrs/week for two or more terms (which can include summer research).
faculty.opportunities: Computational modeling, behavioral experiments, analytical chemistry, molecular cloning and genome engineering, extracellular electrophysiology

faculty.name: Shinsuke Shimojo
faculty.requirements: Some neuroscience, bioengineering, psychology related courses, ability of coding in Matlab, Python or C++.
faculty.students: Lily Kitagawa, Steve Guo, Ishani Ganguly, Sara Adams, Anthony Pineci
faculty.opportunities: Assisting human psychophysics (sensation, decision, action) experiments, in coding, running, and analyzing. Human magnetic sensation, Individual and Team flow, visual preference decision, perception and action in the extreme periphery of visual field, etc.

faculty.name: Lu Wei
faculty.requirements: wet lab experience
faculty.opportunities: Work under the mentorship of a graduate student. Help perform experiments and process data.

faculty.name: Bill Goddard
faculty.requirements: ability to use computers, our research uses QM and MD answer problems in  chemistry, materials science, biochemistry
faculty.opportunities: see papers at https://caltech-msc.github.io/publications/pubs-current.html

faculty.name: Scott Cushing
faculty.requirements: Judged on an individual  basis
faculty.opportunities: Contribute to lab on laser-based instrumentation building, involving entangled photons or ultrafast xray pulses, or the theory of the related spectra

faculty.name: Beverley McKeon
faculty.students: Alex Wuschner, Sarah Barrett, Rahul Arun
faculty.opportunities: Various experimental/analytical fluid mechanics

faculty.name: Brent Fultz
faculty.requirements: There are two possibilities. 1) Computational experience. Not so much writing new code, but sorting out workflows through different packages. 2) Laboratory chemistry. We don't do so much conventional chemical synthesis, but we use plasmas and mechanical deformation to make new materials. There is also an effort to measure physical properties by gas adsorption (think plumbing) and electrochemistry (think batteries).
faculty.opportunities: Usually the undergraduate will work on a research project funded by either NSF or DOE. The project is typically part of a Ph.D. thesis of a graduate student, who needs some help. The work may not be in the critical path, though. Reconfiguring measurement instruments and rewriting the software for them is typical project. Sometimes making electrochemical cells and testing them is a good project, but this usually requires regular presence in the lab.

faculty.name: Adam Wierman
faculty.requirements: It depends on the project, but typically projects require students to have proficiency with programming and experience with algorithms, Game Theory, and optimization.

faculty.name: Steven Low
faculty.requirements: Math, software.  Ideally power systems ee/cs 135
faculty.opportunities: EV charging, smart grids research

faculty.name: Lihong Wang
faculty.requirements: At least 10 hours/week
faculty.opportunities: Work with senior lab members on optical imaging to learn and contribute

faculty.name: Azita Emami
faculty.requirements: EE44, EE45, EE10, basic knowledge of electronic systems
faculty.opportunities: Design and implementation of biomedical devices

faculty.name: Michelle Effros
faculty.requirements: Strong mathematical skills -- with specific strengths in mathematical proofs using tools from probability and linear algebra.  Demonstrated interest in biology and especially neuroscience is a plus.
faculty.opportunities: Investigation of the performance of probabilistic models of neurons and their relationship to basic brain functions.

faculty.name: Guillaume Blanquart
faculty.requirements: Preferred, but not required: basic Linux, Matlab, thermodynamics (ME11a), fluid mechanics (ME 11c).  That being said, I will work with the student(s) and their respective background.
faculty.students: SURF 2019: Moya Ly, Matthew Szedlock, Limbert Palomino
faculty.opportunities: Running numerical simulations (anything from chemistry to fluid mechanics).  Analyzing data (often with Matlab).  Applied math (rarely because more background is necessary).

faculty.name: Michael Lamb
faculty.requirements: ability to work with hands, shop skills, matlab, granular mechanics, earth science, fluid mechanics, engineering
faculty.opportunities: Help conduct physical experiments on sediment transport in rivers on earth and mars

faculty.name: Francois Tissot
faculty.requirements: Either a strong quantitative background for modeling projets, or a great potential for lab work (strong critical thinking, attention to details, tidiness and dexterity)
faculty.opportunities: Isotope geo and cosmochemistry related projects, modeling or measurements (or both)

faculty.name: John Eiler
faculty.requirements: 1) computer programming appropriate to numerical and statistical modeling (including machine learning) and GUI's; 2) synthetic chemistry; 3) analytical chemistry and geochemistry; 4) first-principles computational chemistry
faculty.opportunities: Contributions to the study of molecular isotopic structures of natural and synthetic materials, with applications to prebiotic chemistry, origin and early evolution of life, biogeochemistry, and fundamental chemistry of isotopes

faculty.name: Dianne Newman
faculty.requirements: academic interests: microbiology, genetics, (bio)chemistry, quantitative biology; personal qualities: maturity, strong worth ethic, reliability, enthusiasm
faculty.opportunities: My laboratory studies how microbes thrive when oxygen is scarce. We study the cellular and molecular strategies that enable them to do this, motivated by contexts ranging from chronic infections to the rhizosphere (soil near the roots of plants). Specific opportunities will be matched to the interests/skills of the student.Â

faculty.name: Andy Thompson
faculty.requirements: Helpful if taken ESE 102, but not required.
faculty.opportunities: Activities will depend on the research project.  Most of the work involves working with idealized models of the ocean's circulation and/or working with ocean data sets.  The latter includes both remote sensing products and data sets collected by autonomous vehicles.

faculty.name: Dianne Newman

faculty.opportunities: My laboratory studies how microbes thrive when oxygen is scarce. We study the cellular and molecular strategies that enable them to do this, motivated by contexts ranging from chronic infections to the rhizosphere (soil near the roots of plants). Specific opportunities will be matched to the interests/skills of the student.Â

faculty.name: Diana Kormos Buchwald
faculty.requirements: MS Office; Adobe; Excel; knowledge of physics and or history desirable but not necessary.
faculty.students: Maggie Anderson, Madison Lee, Camilla Ora, Alex Guerra, Hongsing
faculty.opportunities: Various projects requiring research into libraries; coding and database work; image recognition techniques

faculty.name: Ralph Adolphs
faculty.requirements: Must have coding experience, preferably in Python
faculty.students: Rae Moar, Louis Santos, Roshan Bal, Isabella Camplisson
faculty.opportunities: Working on human data, likely either brain imaging data and/or eyetracking data; applying machine learning algorithms to find patterns in the data.  Will work with graduate students and/or post-docs in the lab.

faculty.name: Paul Bellan
faculty.requirements: Computer skills with large data sets, some physics knowledge
faculty.opportunities:
In a new initiative between Caltech and Los Alamos National Lab (LANL),   existing experimental sets of kink instability data collected at Caltech over the past years will be archived in a manner that machine learning (ML) techniques can be applied to them. The  goal is to demonstrate ML for studying the kink instability physics, such as prediction of kink rise time and growth rate, and to compare the results with theory and simulations. 

As a first step, the existing Caltech datasets will be archived by a Caltech undergraduate at a shared drive or multiple mirror sites at Caltech and LANL. The archiving effort include turning the raw data into the uniform format of .tif without resolution reduction from the originals, and documenting the experimental conditions for each data set in Word and/or Excel including X-ray images, related diagnostic data and experimental conditions.

faculty.name: Rana Adhikari
faculty.requirements: Curiosity! .....also good to have interest/experience in lasers, electronics, control systems, signal processing
faculty.opportunities: Laser interferometry, low noise measurements,

faculty.name: Scott Cushing
faculty.requirements: Judged on an individual  basis
faculty.opportunities: Contribute to lab on laser-based instrumentation building, involving entangled photons or ultrafast xray pulses, or the theory of the related spectra

faculty.name: Lynne Hillenbrand
faculty.requirements: basic computing and statistics knowledge; prefer ay20
faculty.students: Arlindo Chan Borges ; Alix Reeves; Philip Carr
faculty.opportunities: Analysis of astronomical spectra and photometry of young stars.

faculty.name: Evan Kirby
faculty.requirements: proficiency in Unix and Python
faculty.students: AJ Nielsen, Tawny Sit, Gianluca Delgado, Joshua Anderson, Noah Yared
faculty.opportunities: Opportunities to work with spectroscopy from the Keck telescopes and to simulate spectroscopy from the upcoming Prime Focus Spectrograph on the Subaru Telescope.  Measure the compositions of stars and the dark matter content of galaxies.  All research opportunities involve heavy doses of programming and statistics.

faculty.name: Philip Hopkins
faculty.requirements: Some interest in astronomy and physics, ideally some background in those areas (but not required). Some familiarity with basic coding (e.g. Python or C), sufficient to make a plot or read a file, is required, more advanced coding backgrounds encouraged (increasing the range of possible projects).
faculty.students: Dhruv Muley (SURF 2019), Grace Lawrence (Summer 2018), Anise Rau (SURF 2018), Andrew Rothstein (SURF 2018), Tianyi (Amy) Hu (Senior thesis 2016), Clarke Esmerian (Senior thesis 2016), Matthias Raives (Senior thesis 2015), Daniel Cushey (SURF 2017), Ben Calvin (SURF 2017), Stefania Moroianu (CamSURF 2017), Eric Moseley (Senior thesis 2017), Rafae Fuyo-Gomez (SURF 2016), Gefei Dang (SURF 2016), Charles Watson (SURF 2016).
faculty.opportunities: Our group studies the formation of planets, stars, galaxies, and black holes, and astrophysical fluid dynamics, primarily using numerical simulations. Students working with us have worked on a wide range of projects over the last few years: most involve running or analyzing simulations of some astrophysical phenomena (e.g. a cosmological simulation of galaxies forming), and trying to understand the physics that gives rise to some observed phenomenon (either by exploring simulations with different physical laws or parameters, and/or via comparison to state-of-the-art observations). Students always work with myself and a postdoc or advanced graduate student as co-mentors.
